Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to create an integrated food-energy-water system that uses agricultural waste to generate a high-protein food product. Large-scale use of agricultural waste (mostly leafy greens) as a food source for mealworms, which are a dry-goods pests and do not survive on wet foods. This project will develop a passive solar dryer to dry agricultural waste on a large scale with very little energy input and high efficiency so that it can be set up any where in the world near agricultural fields. This system for producing protein for human consumption is designed to have a water-use footprint close to zero.

This I-Corps project will develop the large-scale use of agricultural waste (mostly leafy greens) as a food source for mealworms. Second, mealworms are dry-goods pests and do not survive on wet foods. This project will develop a passive solar dryer to dry agricultural waste on a large scale with very little energy input. It is the company's intent to develop the dryer with minimal moving parts and high efficiency so that it can be set up any where in the world near agricultural fields. Third, this system for producing protein for human consumption is designed to have a water-use footprint close to zero. Mealworms growth performance increases dramatically at high relative humidity. The passive solar dryer will dehydrate the agricultural waste to a dryness appropriate for the mealworms. The water released during desiccation will be recaptured and reused to humidify the mealworm rearing facility. Together, the intellectual merit lies in an integrated system to produce a high quality food source with minimal energy and water need, that can be set up relatively inexpensively anywhere in the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this award was to conduct customer discovery to determine the viability of starting a company to grow insects as food and feed. We conducted well over 250 interviews and based on what we learned, we established a startup company called HexaFeast LLC. We are in the process of tech transfer of licenses from the University of Arizona to HexaFeast. The goal of HexaFeast is to develop the yellow mealworm (larvae of the beetle Tenebrio molitor, Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae) as a high-protein food product for human consumption. The use of the yellow mealworm is seeing a dramatic increase in the food and feed industries. The intellectual property of this project has two components. First, we are developing proprietary feed for the yellow mealworm based on agricultural and food waste. Second, we are developing the processing technology of the agricultural waste itself that minimizes energy and water consumption. HexaFeast has identified a need for accessible insect rearing systems that economically, efficiently and sustainably produce edible insects. We also have identified a strong and growing market for insect rearing system products and knowledge, which is an underlying data point we will continue to explore.  The HexaFeast innovation creates an efficient and environmentally sustainable mealworm rearing system that produces the highest quality mealworms for sale as functional food ingredients. The resulting products are both the technology, for customers interested in farming insects, and the resulting product, various forms of processed and raw mealworms. Despite that, there is a growing market and high unmet demand for edible insect ingredients and thus increasing interest for farming insects commercially, there are not any farming systems available for sale and most related technology and knowledge is being developed by private companies and not commercially available.

 


Last Modified: 02/03/2021
Modified by: Goggy Davidowitz
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The purpose of this award was to conduct customer discovery to determine the viability of starting a company to grow insects as food and feed. We conducted well over 250 interviews and based on what we learned, we established a startup company called HexaFeast LLC. We are in the process of tech transfer of licenses from the University of Arizona to HexaFeast. The goal of HexaFeast is to develop the yellow mealworm (larvae of the beetle Tenebrio molitor, Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae) as a high-protein food product for human consumption. The use of the yellow mealworm is seeing a dramatic increase in the food and feed industries. The intellectual property of this project has two components. First, we are developing proprietary feed for the yellow mealworm based on agricultural and food waste. Second, we are developing the processing technology of the agricultural waste itself that minimizes energy and water consumption. HexaFeast has identified a need for accessible insect rearing systems that economically, efficiently and sustainably produce edible insects. We also have identified a strong and growing market for insect rearing system products and knowledge, which is an underlying data point we will continue to explore. The HexaFeast innovation creates an efficient and environmentally sustainable mealworm rearing system that produces the highest quality mealworms for sale as functional food ingredients. The resulting products are both the technology, for customers interested in farming insects, and the resulting product, various forms of processed and raw mealworms. Despite that, there is a growing market and high unmet demand for edible insect ingredients and thus increasing interest for farming insects commercially, there are not any farming systems available for sale and most related technology and knowledge is being developed by private companies and not commercially available.
